importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the incident when Houthi rebels detained UN employees and raided a UN facility in Sanaa, marking a significant escalation in the conflict over humanitarian operations in Yemen.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The ongoing timeline of Houthi actions against UN personnel and operations, indicating a persistent pattern of interference and detention that has disrupted humanitarian efforts in Yemen.

keyTakeAways: Iranian-backed Houthi rebels detained 20 UN employees in Sanaa's Hada neighborhood, including five Yemenis and 15 international staff.
The rebels confiscated all communication equipment from the facility, including phones, servers, and computers.
The detained staff belong to multiple UN agencies such as the World Food Program, UNICEF, and the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.
The Houthis have conducted repeated raids and detentions of UN personnel across Yemen, including in Saada and Hodeida, alleging espionage without evidence.
The UN has consistently denied accusations of espionage and has suspended operations in Saada, relocating its top humanitarian coordinator to Aden.
A World Food Program worker died in detention earlier this year in Saada, highlighting the dangers faced by humanitarian staff.
The UN is actively engaging with Houthi rebels and other parties to resolve the detention and restore control over its facilities in Sanaa.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Iranian-backed Houthi rebels in Yemen detained 20 United Nations staff members in Sanaa’s Hada neighborhood, including five Yemenis and 15 international personnel, and confiscated all communication equipment from the facility. The detainees include staff from the World Food Program, UNICEF, and the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. This incident follows a broader pattern of Houthi raids and detentions across Yemen, including in Saada and Hodeida, where they have repeatedly accused international staff of espionage—claims the UN has consistently denied. The UN has suspended operations in Saada and relocated its top humanitarian coordinator to Aden, reflecting the escalating risks to humanitarian operations. The incident underscores the deepening tension between humanitarian actors and armed groups in conflict zones, with significant implications for global aid delivery and geopolitical stability.
title: Yemen’s Houthi rebels detain 20 UN employees and confiscate equipment
